loans.name: Helen Abrinica Group

texts.en:
Helen A. is from the village of Pan-ay, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. Helen is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Helen is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Helen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,009 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Helen is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP that will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Helen from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

Nida is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP that will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Nida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Lumière Group

texts.fr:
Lumière est un regroupement de femmes de Koury (préfecture de Yorosso région de Sikasso) qui se connaissent bien car elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 48 ans, sont 9 mariées et 1 veuve, mères d’au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, la vente de peau   de bœufs séchées, la restauration,  la vente de céréales, de condiments etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Aïcha N. qui  est un membre du groupe lumière vend de la peau de bœuf séchée.  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une quantité importante de peau, à Sikasso, Mopti et à Koury auprès des bouchers et effectue sa vente à  Accra, la capitale ghanéenne, à une clientèle diverse et variée qui à leur tour prépare pour manger ou vendre. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 110 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Aïcha N. compte réaliser 150 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Lumière is a grouping of women from Koury (in the prefecture of Yorosso in the region of Sikasso) who know each other well because they all live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They average 48 years of age, with nine of them being married and the tenth a widow, and they are all mother to at least four children. This group of women carry out a variety of different trades including the sale of dried ox skins, restauration, sale of cereals and condiments etc.. In order to expand their activities, the members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program a year ago. They are on their third group loan and all the previous loans have been repaid on time. Aïcha N., who is a member of the Lumière group, sells dried ox skins. With her loan she is planning on buying a significant quantity of skins from butchers in Sikasso, Mopti and Koury; she sells them in Accra, the capital of Ghana, to a diverse and varied customer base, which in turn prepares the skins to eat or to sell. While the members of the group expect to make a monthly profit of 110,000FCFA each during the course of the cycle, Aïcha N. expects to make 150,000FCFA. As well as repaying their loans, they use a part of their income to cover their families' everyday expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ox skins

loans.name: Anonymous

loans.name: Siguidia (La Joie De Vivre) Group

texts.fr:
Siguidia est un regroupement de femmes de Koury (préfecture de Yorosso, région de Sikasso) qui se connaissent bien car elles  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans, sont 6 mariées et 2 célibataires mères d’au moins 2 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les habillements,  les condiments et la restauration etc. 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année. Elles sont à leur troisième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Moussokoro C. est un membre du groupe Siguidia qui vend des habits et les condiments de toutes sortes (gros oignon, poivre, l’ail Sounbala, fakoye, et divers autres).  
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des habits et condiments. Elle se procure  des habits et condiments à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). Elle vend ses marchandises en détail et au comptant au marché de Koury à la maison et en ambulant à une clientèle diverse et variée elle est très sollicitée. 
Tandis que Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 120 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Moussokoro compte réaliser 135 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnel et s’occuper de son unique garçon.
texts.en:
Siguidia is a grouping of women from Koury (in the prefecture of Yorosso in the region of Sikasso) who know each other well because they live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They average 28 years of age, with six of them being married and two single, and they have at least two children each. This group of women trade in various products such as clothing, condiments and products for restauration. In order to expand their businesses, the members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program a year ago. They are on their third group loan and all their previous loans have been repaid on time. Moussokoro C. is a member of the Siguidia group and sells clothes and condiments of all types (large onions, pepper, garlic, Sounbala (a West African spice), fakoye powder (a Malian herb) and various others). With her loan she is planning to buy clothes and condiments. She gets her clothes and condiments in Bobo Dioulasso in Burkino Faso. She sells her goods on a retail basis for cash at the market in Koury, from home and on a door-to-door basis, to a diverse customer base. She is in great demand. While the members of the group expect to make an average profit of 120,000FCFA each during the cycle, Moussokoro expects to make 135,000FCFA. As well as paying back her loan, she uses part of her income to cover her personal expenses and to take care of her only son.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothes and condiments

loans.name: Sujeewa

texts.en:
Sujeewa is a 37-year-old married woman who lives with her husband and four children (one son and three daughters). 

Sujeewa manages a carpet-weaving business which she started two years ago. She is a hardworking woman and there is good demand for her product. She hopes to start additional businesses in the future.

Sujeewa has requested a 35,000 LKR loan from BRAC Sri Lanka to help with her business.

Thank you for taking the time to consider supporting this Sri Lankan loan!

loans.use: To use as capital for her carpet-weaving business

loans.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Né vers 1963 à Tiby, préfecture de San, Abdoulaye Yaré n’as pas eu la chance de faire de brillantes études, alors il embrassa tôt les activités génératrices de revenus. Il est mari d’une épouse et  père de 12 enfants. Il vit chez lui même dans le quartier Dabani de la préfecture de San (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).  
Abdoulaye opta pour l’achat vente de téléviseurs et accessoires  qu’il a appris  auprès de son grand frère il y a plus de 20 ans.  
Actuellement il exerce pour lui même au grand marché  de San depuis 10 ans.  Il est très sollicité surtout les jours  des foires hebdomadaires de San  ville et environnants.  
Afin de diversifier son activité, il décida de faire recours à l ‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans.  Il est à son 3ème prêt  individuel, après avoir correctement remboursé les deux précédents. 
Monsieur Abdoulaye  compte acheter, différentes sortes de  télévisions, de DVD et VCD(écran 14, 21 et 26) avec ce prêt. 
Il s’approvisionnait  auprès des commerçants grossistes de San, mais avec l’augmentation du fonds de commerce, il compte aller juste qu’a Lomé ( capitale de Togo).  Il  vend  dans sa boutique au grand marché de San et dans les foires hebdomadaires à une clientèle constituée  de femmes et d’hommes à crédit ou au comptant. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 175.000FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt, payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants, acheter la nourriture et investir le reste dans d’autres activités de revenus .
texts.en:
Born in 1963 in Tiby, in the San Prefecture, Abdoulaye Yaré did not have the opportunity to excel in school, so he embraced revenue-generating activities at an early age. He is married and the father of 12 children. He lives at home in the Dabani borough of the San Prefecture (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Over 20 years ago, he opted for the commerce of televisions and related accessories, a business he learned from his older brother. For the past ten years he has been running his own business at the main market in San. He is in high demand, particularly during the weekly market fairs in San and surrounding areas. To diversify his activities, he decided two years ago to call upon the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. He is requesting a third individual loan, having fully reimbursed the two preceding ones. Mr. Abdoulaye will use this loan to buy different televisions, DVD and VCD players (with 14, 21, and 26-inch screens). He used to get his supplies from wholesalers in San, but as he increased his working capital, he now would like to go as far as Lomé (the capital of Togo). He sells in his shop at San’s main market and in weekly market fairs, to a customer base of both men and women, for cash or credit. He is hoping to attain monthly earnings of 175,000 FCFA he will use to reimburse the loan, pay his children’s tuition fees, buy food, and reinvest the remainder in other revenue-generating activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy electronic appliances

loans.name: Nakinyuguzi 2 Kakembo Hellen Group

loans.name: Sidiki

texts.fr:
Né 13 janvier 1982 à San  préfecture de San, Sidiki Traoré n’as pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, il a  donc très vite embrassé les activités génératrices de revenus. Il est mari d’une épouse et  père de 2 enfants. Il vit chez lui même dans le quartier Santoro I de la préfecture de San.  
Sidiki exerce l’achat vente de colas en gros et en détail  qu’ il a appris  auprès de son père  il y a plus de 10 ans , et l’exerce actuellement pour lui même au grand marché  de San depuis  5 ans.  Il est très sollicité lors  des foires hebdomadaire de San  ville et environnants.  
Pour diversifier son activité, il décida de faire recours à l‘institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso et est à son 2ème prêt individuel. 
Monsieur Sidiki compte acheter 30 paniers de colas, (s’il s’approvisionnait auprès des commerçants grossistes de San), avec l’augmentation du fonds de commerce, il compte aller jusqu’à Bouaké (République de Côte d’Ivoire) pour son approvisionnement il  vend tous les jours, au grand marché de San et dans les foires hebdomadaires à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’hommes à crédit ou au comptant. 
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 15.000 FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt et utiliser  le reste pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Born in 1982 in San, in the Prefecture of San, Abdoulaye Yaré did not have the opportunity to go to school, so he embraced revenue-generating activities at an early age. He is married and the father of two children. He lives at home in the Santoro I borough of the San Prefecture. Sidiki practices the commerce of cola nuts, both wholesale and retail, learned from his father over ten years ago. He has been running his own business at the main market in San for the past five years, and is in high demand during the weekly market fairs in San and surrounding areas. To diversify his activities, he decided to call upon the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. He is now requesting a second individual loan. Mr. Sidiki wants to buy 30 baskets of cola nuts. He used to get his supplies from wholesale merchants in San, but as he increased his working capital, he now would like to go as far as Bouaké (Republic of Côte d’Ivoire). He sells every day at the main market in San and in weekly market fairs, to a customer base of both men and women, for cash or credit. He is hoping to attain monthly earnings of 15,000 FCFA he will use to reimburse the loan, and with the remainder pay his children’s tuition fees.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baskets of cola nuts

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata Traoré est âgée  de 40 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame avec son époux, ses deux coépouses et leurs enfants dans le quartier  Médina coura de la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
N’ayant pas eu la chance de faire de brillantes études, elle a embrassé les activités génératrices de revenus depuis son jeune âge qu’elle apprit auprès de sa maman. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus, elle opta finalement pour l’achat vente du bois de chauffe.
Avec une expérience de 20 ans dans  ce créneau, elle est très sollicitée et peut vendre  plusieurs chargements  de camions en bois de chauffe dans la semaine. 
Pour  l’agrandissement de son activité,  Madame Fatoumata a fait  recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui elle est à son 1er prêt  individuel.  
Avec ce financement elle compte acheter  quatre chargements  de camions en de bois dans les  villages environnants de Koutiala pour les revendre  dans le marché de Koutiala  à une clientèle de femmes et d’hommes  à crédit ou au comptant.  
Elle compte sur un bénéfice de 80.000 FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera  pour le remboursement de l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux petites dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré, age 40, is married and the mother of four children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her two co-spouses and their children, in the Médina Coura neighborhood in the town of Koutiala (Sikasso Region). Not having had the chance to pursue brilliant studies, she's been earning money since her youth, which she learned from her mother. After trying several businesses, she finally settled for buying and selling firewood. With 20 years of experience in this market, she's very much in demand and can sell several truckloads of firewood in one week. To bolster her business, Mrs. Fatoumata turned to Kiva's partner, the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which she's seeking her first individual loan. With this loan, she intends to buy four truckloads of firewood in the villages surrounding Koutiala, in order to resell them at the market in Koutiala, on credit or for cash, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She intends to turn a monthly profit of XOF 80'000 (ca US$ 150), to be used to repay the loan and contribute to the family's small expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

texts.en:
For the past 30 years, Yodgor A. has sold different kinds of clothing in the market. She is married and the mother of two children. She is determined to provide a better living for her family. Yodgor is hard working and kind, giving her the ideal blend of entrepreneurial determination and service. Skilled in trade and abounding in character, Yodgor has a strong business base. Currently, she is seeking a loan of 10000 Somoni to purchase a new vending facility and expand her business. With the increased income, Yodgor plans to continue growing her business and to improve the financial situation of her family.       

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. loans.name: Hiloliddin

texts.en:
“Responsible fatherhood” is a term that has been converted into concrete fact in Hiloliddin D.'s life. He has always responded satisfactorily to his role as provider for his two children, for whom he cares with much love, in the company of his wife, who is always supportive of him. Hiloliddin works in agricultural activities and has some cattle. At the moment, he is working intensively at his agricultural activities and taking care of his fields. His wife is helping take care of the cows and also sells their milk. They do all this hard work because they want to give an education to each of their two children. They would also like to open a small business some day; until then they will continue working in their fields. To do this, Hiloliddin is requesting a loan of 8000 Somoni to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

loans.use: To purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Livistone

texts.en: Livistone is a married man with three children.  He offers motorbike transport to earn a living.  He has been in the business for three years.  He is a member of NRBI Lussaco group, and he saves his money with them on weekly basis.  This savings has helped him invest in his business.  His group members have guaranteed him a loan of Kes 30,000. With this loan, he plans to buy spare parts for his motorbike.  He hopes to own several motorbikes in the future.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for his motorbike

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sulaimonkul

texts.en:
E. Sulaimonkul is a young, married man who breeds calves in a small village in the Shahristan district of the Sugd region. Sulaimonkul is full of energy and he tries every single day to make the life of his family better. Sulaimonkul started his business many years ago. He continued the business of his father, who is now a pensioner. Sulaimonkul has great experience in cattle breeding because he observed the work during his childhood. He would like to expand his business and purchase more calves. This will help him to increase his income and improve his family's life conditions. IMON International wishes him good luck and appreciates your help!

loans.use: Purchasing cattle in order to expand business

loans.name: Mckeown Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Akosua is a 53-year-old woman who describes herself as trustworthy.  She is married to a gardener and together they have two children who are 14 and 17 years old.  She would like to support her children’s education up to the tertiary level. Akosua has operated a retail palm oil business for the past year.  She also sells 'gari' to supplement her income.  Gari is a fried cassava dish.  She will use the loan to buy palm oil and 'gari'.  She hopes to eventually become a palm oil wholesaler.  

Akosua is currently the leader of the trust bank group called 'McKeown'.  Akosua believes that she was elected group leader because she is educated, humble and hard-working.  There are 9 members in the group.  The other members of the group are involved in trade businesses such as chop bar (food stall) operator, yam selling, and clothes selling. They plan to use the loan to purchase various items to grow their business to support their family.

loans.use: To purchase palm oil and gari in bulk

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 34-year-old married lady who has two children, aged eleven and four.  She operates Neema Retailers, a retail shop, to earn a living.  She also does welding, with the help of her husband, in order to earn extra income to support their family. She previously sold clothes before venturing into this business.  She is an active member of Hope Group in Faulu, Kenya. Hope Group's members guarantee each other loans.  She has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 to buy sugar, maize, flour and rice.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize, flour and rice

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is a 30-year-old married man who has two children, both of whom go to school.  He operates a laundry shop and has hired one person.  He has six years of experience in this business. He also sells newspapers to earn extra income.  He uses his income to support his family and educate his children. He has been an active member of Miracle group in Faulu Kenya, and he pays his weekly dues consistently.  He has requested Kes 25,000 from Faulu Kenya. He plans to use this loan to buy a dryer machine. He hopes to own many laundry shops in the future.

loans.use: To purchase a dryer machine

loans.name: Akbarali

texts.en:
M. Akbarali is an active 38-year-old father. He is a talented farmer and his crops are sought after by many local women who would like to sell them. The income he earns from this business allows him to take care of his large family of four children and his wife. Akbarali would like to increase his harvest in order to maximize his income, and to do so he needs to buy fertilizer, fuels and lubricants. As he lacks the financial means to do so, Akbarali is requesting a loan of 7000 Somoni to help him with this purchase.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is a 44-year-old married man who is blessed with five children.  He has been practicing dairy farming for ten years.  He is the breadwinner in his family and for this reason he strives in his business to provide for the family.  Step by Step is a group in Faulu Kenya with whom Paul saves his money on weekly basis.  He is an active member of the group and he attends the group meetings regularly.  He has requested for a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy a dairy cow.  He plans to add more dairy cows so that he can stabilize his business.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

IMON has given Zulfiya loans for 5 years. For the entire period, she has shown herself to be an accurate client. Today she requests 5000 Somoni to purchase new goods to sell. Zulfiya promises to pay the loan in time and thanks everyone for supporting her.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is 22 years old. He is engaged and currently lives alone; his parents have passed away. He has been working as an electrician for the past four years. He generally takes projects in private homes. He works independently as a freelance electrician. The loan officer notes that he has a good reputation for his work in his community. 

He is requesting a $1000 loan from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. He plans to use the loan to invest in new tools for his business. This will be his first loan from Ameen.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). loans.name: Omina

texts.en:
Omina R. is 49 years old. She is married and has one child. With the purpose of supporting her family, Omina sells men's clothing. She has been in this business for 17 years. In these years, she has gained experience choosing goods that are of good quality and meet the requirements of clients with various levels of income. The business is very stable and allows Omina to improve her family's life. Omina has been working with IMON for more than two years. She managed her previous loans with accuracy and made all the payments in a timely manner. Today, Omina requests 5000 Somoni in order to expand her inventory. Omina would like to thank everyone for supporting her.

texts.en:
Dilbar R. is 40 years old. She is married and has five children. Dilbar sells women's clothes and shoes at the market. She has been in this trade for many years. She has proven herself to be an honest and communicative businesswoman. Dilbar is hoping to take a loan of $1500 USD to increase the variety of inventory in her store and keep her business running successfully. This purchase will enable her to increase her sales, to earn more, and to meet the education expenses of her children.

loans.use: Increase inventory variety and working capital

loans.name: Suro Nipa Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Bernice is  a 33-year-old woman who describes herself as reliable and trustworthy.  She has 2 children ages 1 and 10 years old.  Bernice’s family goals include providing her children with the opportunity to future their education.  

Bernice has operated a retail business selling provisions (groceries) for the past 4 years.  She will use the loan to buy bags of rice, gallons of oil, Milo (a cocoa drink), sardines and other food items.  Bernice would like to expand her business.  

Bernice is the leader of the trust bank group named "Sura Nipa", which means “be careful of man” in Twi, the language most commonly spoken in Ghana.  As group leader, Bernice describes herself as firm, fair, and very understanding to all group members.  There are 12 members in this group.  The other group members are engaged in petty trading such as selling foodstuffs, vegetables, fish etc. They plan to use the loan to purchase stock to grow their business and thus provide more support for their family.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk

loans.name: Bikhodjal

texts.en:
Bikhodjal E. is 56 years old. She is widow with 4 children. Bikhodjal sells dried fruit in the central local market. She has been in this business for many years. Dried fruit is very popular in Tajikistan. Any hostess keeps a store of dried fruit at her house in case she has guests. Moreover, dried fruit is always served at family occasions like wedding parties, birthday parties, etc. Considering the constant demand for these goods, Bikhodjal's business is quite successful and brings in stable income for her family. Today, Bikhodjal requests 7000 Somoni for purchasing dried fruit, with the purpose of increase her range of goods. Bikhodjal has already demonstrated herself as an accurate client with a positive credit history. She would like to thank everyone for their support and she promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 35-year-old single woman. She lives with one parent. She is the sole income provider for her household. She owns a clothing shop for women. She has owned this shop since 2009. 
 
She is requesting a $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. She plans to buy new merchandise for her shop. This will be her first loan from Ameen. 

Women entrepreneurs are still in the minority in Lebanon, but they are gaining a greater presence in the country’s labor market. Ameen s.a.l. offers additional incentives to loan officers for offering microloans to prospective clients as well for recruiting female clients.

loans.name: Rahimboy

texts.en:
Rahimboy K. is married and has four children. He runs a business selling coal at the market. Rahimboy has been in business for over 13 years. He has his own car and brings his goods from the neighboring town himself. Rahimboy is a high achiever and a consistent entrepreneur who is very knowledgeable about the market environment. His professional skills and perseverance have helped to ensure the rapid growth and success of his business. Rahimboy is requesting a loan for 13000 Somoni to increase the assortment of his inventory. He is hoping that this loan will help his venture grow and generate extra profits. We believe that Rahimboy's ability to identify tasks critical to business success and set up a system for accomplishing them will allow him to continue growing in the sphere of private entrepreneurship.

loans.use: Increasing inventory of coal

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. is married and has three children to look after, two of whom are still in school. Unable to meet the material needs of her children, she sought assistance from GHAPE when she joined the program in 2007. Her dedication to the program is unquestionable and her hard work has left untold results on the situation of her family.

With her new loan, she plans to buy groundnuts. She plans to keep a good quantity of stalk so that she can resell them when groundnuts are scarce in supply and demand is high. The profit she gets from the loans will be used to educate her children and provide food for her family.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying and selling groundnuts

She is very nice and polite and has many clients. The business is quite stable and serves as a significant source of income for the family. Kholiskhon has been a client of IMON for almost a year and this is her second loan from our organization. She managed to pay all her loans accurately and precisely. Now she requests $3000 USD. Kholiskhon is planning to purchase women's summer clothes to sell. She deeply appreciates your support and sincerely thanks all of you.

This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 29-year-old single woman. She lives with her parents and three siblings. Four members of her household also work. She has owned a shop for gifts, accessories, and toys since 2005. She has a computer in her shop to help her with her work. 

She is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. She plans to use the loan to increase her store’s inventory. The loan officer notes that she has been an excellent client throughout her time with Ameen.

loans.use: To increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Mary Asunkwain

texts.en:
Born in 1977, Mary is married to a very supportive husband. They are blessed with four children. They have had some challenges because of a rural exodus for greener pastures from the urban city of Bamenda. Farmlands are scare or far from their residence in Nkwen, a quarter of Bamenda, Cameroon. This means that they trek very long distances to farm. Her desire to give her children love and the best education motivated her to become a GHAPE member in 2007.  Her past loan investments are still yielding good dividends. She plans to invest this loan in the purchase of beans, palm oil, groundnuts and yams. Mary plans to actively involve her entire family in implementing this phase of her business.

With the profit from this loan, Mary plans to take care of her family, ensure that they eat well and buy their medication.  She knows very well that she will be able to repay this loan because of the low interest rate and the lengthy repayment period. Moreover, last year Anna was able to make savings through which she acquired a piece of farmland.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.

loans.use: To purchase beans, palm oil, groundnuts and yams

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 33-year-old married man. He is the sole income provider for his wife and five children. He has been working in the agriculturA. industry for almost 10 years. He grows a wide variety of vegetables using large plastic tents. These tents allow him to grow more types of products throughout the year. He is well established in his business and has a wide range of tools and equipment to help with his work. The loan officer notes that he has a good reputation in his community.

He is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to install new plastic tents on his farm. This will be his first loan from Ameen.

Note: Based on the politicA. and sociA. challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financiA. services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To install new plastic tents on his farm

loans.name: Ddembe Gayaza, Mubende Group

texts.en:
K. Madina’s main source of livelihood for the past five years has come from selling foodstuffs in Kigunda trading centre in the neighborhood of Mubende Town. It’s with savings from this business that she has managed to sustain her family of five children. The 45-year-old dynamic business lady has reached a point where profits accruing to her business now amount to 320,000 Ugandan shillings a month.

With steady progress in building her small enterprise, Madina reckons her future prospects are rising every passing day. With a loan coming her way, she carries conviction that she will be able to buy more produce like maize, cassava, peanuts, beans and rice, so that she does not run short of supplies.

loans.use: To purchase more produce for her business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 28-year-old married man. He is the sole income provider for his wife and two children. He has been working in the construction industry for eight years. He specializes in installing the cement foundation in walls. He has one person who works with him part-time. He has been running an independent business since 2004. He made the decision to start his own business despite having the opportunity to work in the agricultural industry with his father.

He is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. He plans to use the loan to purchase new tools for his business. This will be his first loan from Ameen. 

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement for its micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his business

loans.name: Mabothraneh Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale business people in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a Kiva partner, to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 500,000, they will be able to add more stock, make more sales, and make more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school and feeding and clothing them.

Isatu C. (3rd from left) is the leader of this group. She was born in Port Loko about forty-five years ago. Isatu has one child who is already a grownup and living on his own.

Isatu sells medicines and has been doing this business for ten years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy more drugs to add to her business.

In the photo is also shown loan officer Zainab B., handing over the loan to the group.

loans.use: To buy more medicines to add to her business

loans.name: Work Together Group

texts.en:
These are members of the “Work Together” group. They are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. This will be their first loan from SMT/Kiva.  With the help of this loan, these entrepreneurs will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and better profit. Consequently, their living standards will improve, they can at least provide three meals a day for their children, pay their schools fees, buy them clothes to wear, and pay their medical bills in case any of them fall sick. 

Aminata S. (pictured fourth from left) is the leader of this group. Aminata was born in a small town call Mile Ninety-One. She is 50 years of age, a widow with two children who are now grownups. Aminata has been a businesswoman for many years. She sells rice, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), Maggie (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, groundnut/peanuts, etc. With the help of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items in wholesale to add to her current stock.

(In the photo is also loan officer Zainab B. handing over the loan to the group).

loans.use: To buy rice, palm oil, Maggie, salt, groundnuts/peanuts, etc

loans.name: Ta-Landeneh Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Ta-Landeneh” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Aminata K. who is pictured on the left. Aminata is 40 years old.  She was born in a place call Makali. Her husband is a professional worker and her children are attending both primary and secondary schools. For five years now, Aminata has been selling locally dyed clothes call “gara lappers”. With her share of the loan, she will invest in her business by buying materials like inks, caustic soda, powder, white cotton, etc. to make gara lappers.

loans.use: To buy inks, caustic soda, powder, white cotton, etc.

loans.name: Faithful Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Faithful” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Rugiatu M. (pictured third from left) is the leader of this group. Rugiatu is married to a security guard and they have three children. Rugiatu has been a businesswoman for three years now. She sells locally dyed cloths called “gara lappers”. With her share of this loan, she will buy materials like white cotton, caustic soda, inks, powder, rubber bowls, hand gloves, etc. to make more gara lappers in order to further expand her business. 

(In the photo is also loan officer Zainab B. who is handing over the loan to the group).

loans.use: To buy white cotton, caustic soda, inks, powder, rubber bowls, hand gloves, etc. to make gara lappers

loans.name: Na We Cam Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Na We Cam” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Kadiatu K. who is age 33. Kadiatu (pictured 3rd from left) was born in Makeni and is married to a diamond dealer with two children. Her husband is a businessman and his children are attending primary school.  For 12 years now, Kadiatu sells jean trousers, T-Shirts, shoes, jewelry, etc. With this loan, she will expand her business by buying the above items in wholesale to add to her business. 

(In the photo is also loan officer Zainab Bangura handing over the loan to the group).

loans.use: To buy jean trousers, T-Shirts, shoes, jewelry, etc.

loans.name: We D Woman Dem Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “We D Woman Den” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses, attract more customers, make more sales and profit and consequently improve their living conditions. 

The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Emma M. who is pictured third from left. She was born in the Yoni Bana village 29 years ago. She is single and has two children. Her children are attending both primary and secondary schools. Emma has been selling shoes, locally dyed cloths (known as gara lappers) and soft drinks for eight years now. With her share of this loan, she will buy shoes, gara-lapper-making-materials like inks, caustic soda, powder, etc. and crates of drinks to add to her business. 

(In the photo is also loan officer Zainab B. handing over the loan to the group).

loans.use: Buy shoes, gara-lapper-making-materials and crates of drinks

loans.name: Kamuyu Group

texts.en:
Memuna F. (left) is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Memuna was born in Makeni city, about 42 years ago. She is married to a businessman and the couple have five  children – one in secondary school, two in primary school and two already grown-up and living on their own. For over 20 years now, Memuna has been selling fish.

This is first loan that Memuna and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Memuna will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to expand her business; she will buy a basket full of fish to add to her current stock of fish. 

(In the photo is also loan officer Zainab Bangura, handing over the loan to the group.)

loans.use: Buy a basket full of fish to add to her current stock

loans.name: Easter Group

texts.en:
These are small-scale businesswomen in the northern city of Makeni. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to seek a loan of SLL 800,000 for each to enable them to expand their businesses. With a loan of SLL 800,000, they will be able to add more stock to their businesses, make more sales, and more profit. Consequently, they will be able to improve their standard of living by sending their children to school, feeding and clothing them. 

Kadiatu C. (pictured receiving the loan) is the leader of this group. She was born in Makeni thirty-one years ago. Kadiatu is married and has two children. Her husband is a tailor and one of her children is attending primary school while the other is still a baby. 

Kadiatu sells slippers and clothes.  She has been doing this business for many years now. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying slippers and clothes to add to her current stock.

In the picture are members of the 'Easter' group and loan officer Daniel Banya, handing over the loan.

loans.use: Buy slippers and clothes to add to her current stock

loans.name: Tokojoja Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra, en su décimo tercer ciclo. Se puede decir que el grupo es muy responsable, todas las integrantes tienen actividades.
Una de las integrantes es la señora Petrona  quien es una mujer muy sacrificada para mantener a sus hijos.
 Ella se dedica a la recolección de productos que se pueden reciclar como de papeles, plásticos y otros.
 Su actividad consiste en salir muy temprano de sus casa y caminar por la calle en busca de cosas que le pueden servir para reciclar y vender, con esta actividad ella mantiene a sus hijos.
Actualmente ella recorre y junta sus reciclados en bolsa que resulta bastante incomodo, pero le gustaría contar con una carretilla que le pueda facilitar el traslado de sus bolsas para ello solicita el préstamo.
texts.en:
This group is now in its tenth loan cycle. You can say that the group is very responsible, all the members having work activities. One of the members is Señora Petrona, a woman who has sacrificed a lot to take care of her children. She works collecting products that can be recycled such as paper, plastic, and other materials. Her work consists of leaving her house very early in the morning and walking through the streets in search of things that she can recycle and sell. This is the work that allows her to provide for her children. At present while walking around she collects her recyclable items in bags, which in quite uncomfortable. She would like to make use of a cart that would help facilitate the transport of the sacks, and that is why she is requesting this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a cart

loans.name: Sesa Me Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Theresa is a 50-year-old married woman with one child, age 16.  She describes herself as trustworthy.  Theresa would like to provide her child with the opportunity to obtain a university level education.  

For the past 15 years, Theresa has operated a trading business where she sells smoked fish.  She also trades in wax cloth (printed fabric) and shoes. She plans to use the loan to purchase more smoked fish.  Her future dream is to open her own shop where she can sell her products.  

Theresa is currently the leader of the 12-member trust bank group named "Sesa Me", which means “Change me” in Twi.  Twi is the language most commonly spoken in Ghana, especially in the Ashanti region.  The other group members are engaged in trades such as smoked fish seller, wax cloth seller and grocery seller. They hope to receive the loan to enable them to buy various stock to grow their businesses and provide more support to their families.

loans.use: To purchase cartons of fish

loans.name: Rukarara Development A, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Very hardworking H. Everlist has been operating a produce sales business in Kazinga, Kihihi, for a period of thirteen years. With nostalgia, this happily married father of five children recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as his business is now showing diminishing returns, earning him 250,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. This is in sharp contrast to the 350,000 shillings he says he was making at the start of his business.

There is always a story connected with people in western Uganda who, despite laboring under such tough times, find a way of educating their children. Everlist is no exception. What he is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing his business by buying more maize, beans, cassava and other crops with the help of this loan.

loans.use: To buying more produce to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 52-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and three children. Two of his children also work to help support the family. He has been working in the agriculturA. industry for over 20 years. He has owned his own farm since 1993. He has one person who assists him part time. 

He is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. He plans to use the loan to invest in new tools for his work. This will be his first loan from Ameen.

Note: Based on the politicA. and sociA. challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financiA. services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To invest in new tools for his work

loans.name: Jhony

texts.es:
La Señor Jhony H. C. 25 años de edad, el se vino a ivirgarzama ya que no pudo encontrar trabajo en Cochabamba él a muy corta edad quedo huérfano y creció con su hermana mayor hasta la edad de 20 años no pudo ingresar a la universidad por dedicarse a trabajar, el se reunió un poco de capital como albañil y monto una pequeña  venta de ropa en el mercado de la playa de autos de ivirgarzama, el se vino a ivirgarzama por el comentario de uno de sus amigos que le dijo que en el trópico  había mercado para los comerciantes el dejo su familia en Cochabamba y se vino para trabajar como comerciante en ivirgarzama. 

El solicita el crédito para la compra de mercadería, y así poder incrementar más sus ingresos para que en un fututo pueda formar una familia.
texts.en:
Mr. Jhony H. C., 25, came to Ivirgarzama since he couldn’t find work in Chochabamba. He was orphaned at a very young age and grew up living with his older sister until he was 20. He couldn’t enter the university because he had to work. He put some money together working as a mason and started selling clothing in the market at the beach of Ivirgarzama. He came to Ivirgarzama because one of his friends told him that in the tropics there was work for salespeople. He left his family in Cochabamba and came to work as a merchant in Ivirgarzama. He is requesting a loan to buy merchandise so that he can increase his income because he wants to start a family in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital (to buy merchandise)

loans.name: Adolfo

texts.es:
La Señor Adolfo Acuña T. tiene 34 años de edad, el vive solo en ivirgarzama, es comerciante de comida.

La Señor Adolfo se dedica a la venta de comida hace como 5 años, su mujer lo dejo hace como 6 años atrás por razones que el mismo desconoce, el jamás estuvo casado ni tubo hijos, el estuvo casi un año tratando de levantarse y volver a dedicarse a su negocio ya que la mujer lo había dejado en la calle sin ningún tipo de mueble, ropa, dinero y con algunas deudas a terceras personas, hoy en día el señora Adolfo volvió a montar su expendio de comida para lo cual le falta un poco de capital ya que el no tiene los medios suficientes para atender bien a sus clientes.

El solicita el crédito para la compra de sillas y mesas para una mejor atención a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Adolfo is 34 years old and lives by himself in Ivirgarzama. He sells food. Mr. Adolfo has been selling food for the past five years. His woman left him six years ago for reasons that are unknown to him. He has never been married or had children. For a year he tried to move ahead. He returned to the business that his woman had left in the street. He didn’t have any furniture, clothes, or money and had a debt to a third party. Today Adolfo’s business has gotten back on its feet but he lacks capital and he doesn’t have sufficient resources to serve his customers well. He is asking for a loan to buy chairs and tables in order to provide his customers with better service.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital (to buy chairs and tables)

loans.name: Nyame Mmre Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Veronica is a 41-year-old woman who describes herself as hard-working.  She is married and has 6 children between the ages of 3 and 18 years old.  She hopes she can help all of her children secure decent jobs. For the past 7 years, Veronica has operated a trading business where she sells yams and bags of rice.  She will use the loan to buy more yams and bags of rice.  Veronica would like to eventually open a big supermarket in her community.

Veronica is the leader of the trust bank group named "Nyame Mmere", which means “God's Time” in Twi.  Twi is the most commonly spoken language in Ghana, especially in the Ashanti region.  There are 7 members in this group.  The other group members are engaged in trades such as charcoal retailer, palm oil retailer, groundnut (also known as peanut) retailer and an egg retailer.  Veronica ensures that all of the members attend meetings and submit timely repayments. She believes that she was elected group leader because she is a unifier.

loans.use: To purchase rice and yams in bulk

loans.name: Hormiguitas Group

texts.es:
Lidia M. P. de 34 años es soltera  vive en la zona Juliana hace 10 años aproximadamente, cuidando una casa, ella tiene el negocio de venta de muñeco de peluches, acomoda sus productos en dos ferias, una de ellas se llama San Luis al cuál va los días lunes y la otra feria se llama Pacajes al cual va los días domingos, en ambos casos vende de 8 de la mañana  hasta las 2 de la tarde, en esta oportunidad necesita el préstamo para comprar mercadería, es decir, más muñecos de peluche. 
Las demás integrantes de esta asociación Hormiguitas tienen variados negocios como: venta de faldas, cosméticos, comida (salchipapa), confección de prendas de bebe, conducción de movilidad y elaboración de camas, todas necesitan el préstamo para adquirir mercadería, insumos o materia prima. 
Ellas se reúnen cada dos semanas en el Centro Focal Collpani.
texts.en:
Lidia is 34 years old, single and has lived in the Juliana Zone for approximately the past ten years. She cares for a house. She sells stuffed animals. She sells them at two markets. One market, called San Luis, is on Mondays. The other market, called Pacajes, she goes to on Sundays. At both markets she sells from 8am until 2pm. She would like this loan in order to buy merchandise. In other words, she would like to buy more stuffed animals. The other members of the “Hormiquitas” (Little Ant) Association have various businesses such as selling skirts, cosmetics, food (pig skins), or baby clothes. They also are drivers or construct beds. Each one needs a loan to buy merchandise, goods or wholesale materials. The members meet every two weeks in the Collpani city center.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Biakoye Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Akua K. is a 52-year-old woman who describes herself as trustworthy.  She is married with 3 adult children.  For the past 4 years, Akua has operated a retail business where she sells items such as toffee and 'gari'.  Gari is a fried cassava dish.  She will use the loan to buy bags of 'gari', sugar and toffee.  Akua would like to eventually open a large supermarket.

Akua is currently the leader of the trust bank group named "Biakoye", which means “Unity” in Twi, the language most commonly spoken in Ghana.  There are 13 members in the group.  The members also operate retail businesses selling items such as fish, yams, and rice. They hope to receive the loan to enable them to buy various stock to grow their businesses and provide more support for their family.

loans.use: To purchase 'gari', sugar and toffees in bulk for resale

loans.name: Rukarara Development Group B, Kihihi

texts.en:
This very determined and hardworking lady is not afraid of diversity when speaking in economic business terms and anything that can earn her profit. K. Suzan, aged 31 years, is happily married with five children and has been in the produce business for one month.

Suzan opened up her grocery, dealing in dry food crops like peas, beans, maize, millet and sorghum, and this loan is to help her buy more stock for resale. This is because she did not have a sound capital base in the beginning. The loan will give her a free ticket to earn more revenue and cater for her family’s basic needs and also acquire a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To buy more peas, beans, maize, millet and sorghum to sell

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Ms. Augustina R. V., 30 years old, is a single mother with two children in school. Very entrepreneurial, Augustina weaves blankets and handmade tablecloths, taking her products monthly to sell in the markets in Luque, which is 100 Km from her city. Thanks to this enterprise she now has her own house and is able to provide a dignified and comfortable life for her children.

Augustina is now requesting a loan that will go towards purchasing thread and colors to weave hammocks, as this is the season when many of her clients are requesting them.

loans.use: To purchase threads and colors

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy mulches and manure for his plantation

loans.name: Mujeres Progresando Group

texts.es:
El comité “Mujeres Progresando”  cumple actualmente su 9no ciclo, sus integrantes  ya se desenvuelven cada una en su propia microempresa.
Una de las microempresarias es la señora Rossana quien posee una tienda donde vende todo tipo de artículos.
Actualmente quiere invertir en su negocio, pero como cuenta con otros gastos familiares solicita el préstamo para cubrirlos.
Ella se dedica a su casa y a su negocio mientras que el marido se dedica a la construcción y plomería,  los dos desean mucho ampliar  el negocio para obtener mejor ganancia y de esa manera mejorar la vivienda que actualmente tienen.  
Todas las integrantes procuran por que desean que sus hijos puedan optar por una buena educación y posteriormente un obtener un empleo por eso agradecen a la Fundación por el apoyo recibido.
texts.en:
The committee “Mujeres Progresando” (Women in Progress) is currently completing its ninth cycle, and its members are all doing very well with their micro-businesses. One of the micro-entrepreneurs is Mrs. Rossana, who has a store where she sells all types of goods. Currently, she wants to invest in her business, but since she has other family expenses, she’s asking for a loan to cover these investments. She takes care of her house and her business while her husband takes care of the construction and plumbing. Both of them really want to grow the business to earn more profits, and in this way make improvements to their home. All the members work hard because they want their children to be able to receive a good education and, later, get a good job. This is why they thank the Foundation for the help they receive.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Personal expenses, gas and light bills

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She lives with her husband and three children. All five members of the household are working. She has more than 17 years of experience in the sewing and tailoring industry. She has owned her own sewing workshop since 2008. Women entrepreneurs are still a minority in Lebanon, but this borrower has not only established her own business but also employs five full-time workers. The loan officer notes that she is very active and has a strong reputation for her high-quality work.

She is requesting a loan of $1.200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. She plans to use the loan to perform maintenance work on her sewing machines. She currently owns seven sewing machines. She told the loan officer that she invests her profits in her business and to recruit new employees. Her story is one great example of how microfinance can positively impact women entrepreneurs and assist in job creation.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to more than 41,000 borrowers and disbursed more than 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To perform maintenance work on her sewing machines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase mulches and hire more laborers

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 55-year old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and three children. Two of his children also work to help support the family. He has been working in the agricultural industry for 15 years. He has been running his own farm since 2001.

He is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. He plans to invest in a new plough for his tractor with the loan. This will be his second loan from Ameen.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to more than 41,000 borrowers and disbursed more than 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To invest in a new plough for his tractor

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 27-year old single man. He is living on his own. He has owned and run a cafeteria since 2006. He employs one part-time worker. He has completed his education through primary school.

He is requesting a loan of $800 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. to invest in new tools and equipment for his cafeteria. This will be his first loan from Ameen. He estimates that the loan will help him increase his profit by 15 percent.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to more than 41,000 borrowers and disbursed more than 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To invest in new tools and equipment for his cafeteria

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more stock for her store

loans.name: Corazón Finca Group

texts.es:
El Bancomunal Corazón FINCA, ubicado en L. Comunidad D. Palca se encuentra en el departamento D. Huancavelica, inicia su tercer ciclo con 10 socias, las cuales se dedican al negocio D. las Artesanías.

Alicia es conviviente, tiene 4 hijos el mayor D. 10 años y el más pequeño D. 4 años, Alicia realiza tejidos a mano como chompas, chullos (gorros D. lana muy abrigadores, típicos D. Perú) y diferentes tipos D. prendas, con su negocio ayuda con los gastos D. casa, aprovecha las ferias para L. venta D. sus productos. Poco a poco su negocio ha ido incrementándose gracias al apoyo que recibe D. su familia. Aprovechará el préstamo que ha solicitado para comprar lanas al por mayor, en cantidad. El sueño D. Alicia es tener una tienda en lugar fijo donD. vender su mercadería.

Lida, es casada, tiene 2 hijos D. 8 y 6 años, los cuales estudian en L. escueL. D. L. Comunidad, Lida se dedica al tejido y a L. crianza D. cuyes. Se inició en el negocio tejiendo chompas, chalinas, medias a pedido D. sus amistades, hacia todo tipo D. tejido por necesidad para poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos D. L. familia, con el primer crédito que recibió compró lanas D. colores, así fue incrementando su mercadería y sus ventas. Su sueño es distribuir su mercadería en mercados grandes.
texts.en:
The Bancomunal Corazón FINCA, located in the community of Palca, department of Huancavelica, is beginning its third cycle, with 10 members who are all artisans. Alicia has four children, the oldest being 10-years-old and the youngest 4, and lives with her partner. Alicia hand-knits sweaters, chullos (caps maD. of very warm yarn, typical of Perú), and different types of garments. Her business helps with household expenses, and she takes advantage of craft fairs to sell her products. Little by little her business has grown thanks to the support she receives from her family. She will take advantage of this loan that she has requested to buy yarn at wholesale prices. Her dream is to have her own shop to be able to sell her merchandise. Lida is married, has two children ages 8 and 6, who study in the community school. Lida works knitting and raising guinea pigs. She started her business knitting sweaters, shawls, and stockings at the request of her friends. She did all types of knitting in order to help her husband with household expenses. With her first loan, she bought colored yarn, and in this way increased her merchandise and sales. Her dream is to sell her products in large markets.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of colored yarn

loans.name: Kyandago Development B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Operating a tea plantation has really transformed his life. Having been encouraged by his wife, B. Elikana has been in this tea-selling business for two years which earns him 90,000 Ugandan shillings weekly. Being a married father of five children, he has been able to cater for family problems including paying the school fees for his children.

This loan will enable Elikana to expand his farm through buying more tea seedlings, thus increasing his capacity to supply the factories which are his market. This will enable him to earn more revenue and live a more sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase  more tea seedlings

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower from Lebanon is a 20-year old single man. He lives with his parents and five siblings. Five of his family members are also working. He has been working as a carpenter for five years. He has been running his own carpentry shop since 2005.

He is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. to buy a car to help him with his work. He is requesting a loan of $1,000. This will be his first loan from Ameen.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to more than 41,000 borrowers and disbursed more than 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To buy a car to help with his work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy boards and beams

loans.name: Kyankyere Twetungure, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Through hustling and toiling, B. John, just 25 years old, has managed to invest in the timber sector for now close to three years. He was driven into this business by the fact that there is a lot of demand in the prevailing market, and this was after he left school since he could not easily get a job in his profession.

With a lot of work requiring timber, like furniture workshops and building and construction, John hopes to expand his business on getting this loan and open up supplying stores in different locations. This will enable him earn more revenue and be able to maintain a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To expand his business through marketing and opening up new locations

loans.name: Migyera Development B, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
In this world, one needs a pinch of extra effort and hard work to earn a living, especially in this era of stiff competition. To maximize this point, B. Leo, aged 40 years, who studied carpentry, has been running a carpentry workshop for ten years where he makes windows and doors for customers.

Having had this enterprise alongside his tea plantation, which earns him an additional income, Leo is therefore seeking this loan to help him purchase materials including wood, nails, and cloth and leather covering materials for chairs. This will deliberately help him to improve the quality of his products on the market and get him more customers, thus more revenue.

loans.use: To purchasing wood, nails and other materials for his workshop

loans.name: Jogueraha Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra, en su décimo segundo ciclo.
Todas las integrantes esta realizando alguna actividad que les genere ingreso y con la ayuda de las asesoras logran abrir o mejorar la actividad que cada una realiza.
Una de las integrantes es la  Sra. Sandra R., su principal actividad es la limpieza de casas de familia en la semana, pero esta actividad lo separa mucho de su familia y quiere independizarse dedicándose a la venta de frutas y verduras desde su casa.
Solicita el préstamo para llevar a cabo el proyecto de venta frutas y verduras (naranjas, manzanas, plátanos, cebollas, tomates, locotes y otros).
texts.en:
This committee finds itself in its tenth cycle. All the members are involved in some type of income-generating activity, and with the help of the group’s advisors, are succeeding in starting or growing the businesses that they are all involved in. One of the members is Mrs. Sandra R.. Her primary business is housecleaning during the week, but this takes her away from her family, and she would like to be more independent by opening and fruit and vegetable stand in her home. She is requesting this loan to make this a reality, selling oranges, apples, plantains, onions, and tomatoes, among others.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Ines

texts.es: Inés,de 40 años, vive con su esposo Nicanor (51) , juntos viven con sus 6 hijos ,en su casa que es propia.Desde hace 5 años se dedica a  la venta de verduras en un mercado muy populoso, que esta alejado de su vivienda , es por esta razón que le es dificultoso viajar durante dos horas diarias para llegar hasta su puesto de venta. Pero al margen de esta dificultad , se siente muy contenta, pues su trabajo la mantiene ocupada durante todo el día, y logra buenas ventas gracias a las constantes compras de sus habituales clientes ,que ha obtenido , gracias a su carisma y espontaneidad, pues siempre esta con una sonrisa en el rostro en el momento de la atención. Inés  siente que si sigue trabajando con mucho empeño , como hasta ahora, logrará buenos resultados . Para más adelante tiene planeado incrementar su capital para ofrecerle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.Es el tercer crédito que tiene con  MFP y siempre se ha caracterizado por ser responsable  y promete ser puntual  en el pago de todas sus cuotas.Tiene pensado invertir el  dinero solicitado en  la compra de mayor cantidad de vegetales, pues durante estos meses tienen bastante demanda , y  así quiere aumentar sus ganancias .
texts.en:
Inés, who is 40-years-old, lives with her husband Nicanor (51-years-old). They live together with their six children in their own home. For five years she has been selling vegetables in a very busy market that is quite far from her home. It is difficult for her to travel two hours each day to be able to get to the market to sell her produce. Aside from the difficult commute, she is quite happy because her work keeps her busy all day, and manages good sales thanks to the ongoing purchases of the repeat-clientele she has earned thanks to her charisma and spontaneity. She always has a smile on her face when she’s taking care of them.

Translated from Spanish by Shaun Haines, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of vegetables

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
María Elena  B. es socia del banco comunal  El Cisne, vive en la comunidad  San Isidro en  la parroquia El Valle ubicada al sureste de la ciudad de Cuenca, colindando con el área urbana de la cuidad. Limita al norte con la parroquia Paccha, al este con la parroquia Santa Ana, al sur con la parroquia Tarqui, y al oeste con la parroquia Turi y la ciudad de Cuenca. LA  agricultura y  ganadería son las actividades tradicionales de los pobladores de éste sector, además  tiene como atractivo turístico  la laguna de Cochapamba  llena de totoras y su hermoso paisaje, Rayoloma un sitio ideal para poder admirar en su gran extensión a la ciudad de Cuenca entre otros.

Nuestra socia tiene 37 años de edad, es casada y en su unión conyugal ha concebido 5 hijos que se encuentran de 17, 14, 12, 10, y 2 años, su primer hijo no estudia y ayuda en las labores de la casa, su segundo hijo estudia en la secundaria  y el de 10 años estudia en una escuela de la comunidad, su esposo es de profesión albañil, gracias al trabajo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

María Elena se dedica a la venta de ollas y sartenes pero solo los días domingos recorriendo con sus artículos en su sector desde hace cuatro años, también cría animales como gallinas, vacas y la leche que obtiene de ellas es para el consumo de su hogar. 
Se encuentra nueve años trabajando con los prestamos del bankito y los créditos le  han beneficiado tanto en su hogar como en su negocio, con el dinero que recibirá del credito solicitado comprará ollas, sartenes, etc. para abastecer su negocio.

Su meta es llegar a tener un capital propio para  incrementar su negocio con menaje de cocina y otros articulos para el hogar.
texts.en:
María Elena B. is a member of the comunal bank El Cisne. She lives in the communityho f San Isidro in the parish of El Valle, located to the southeast of the city of Cuenca, adjoining the urban area of the city. It is bordered to the north by the parish of Paccha, to the east by Santa Ana, to the south by Tarqui, and to the west by Turi and the city of Cuenca. Agriculture and cattle are the traditional activities of the people of this area, and it also has the tourist attraction of Lake Cochapamba, full of reeds and its beautiful landscape, and Rayoloma, an ideal place to admire its reach to the city of Cuenca (among other attractions). Our member is 37-years-old, married, and has 5 children ages 17, 14, 12, 10, and 2 years. Her first child isn’t in school, and helps with household chores. Her second is in high school, and the 10-year-old attends a community school. Her husband is a bricklayer, and thanks to their combined work, they have managed to build their own home. María Elena sells pots and pans, but only on Sundays. She has been doing this for four years all around the area where she lives.
